Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
Data:
Hue first impressions. The box arrived a few minutes ago and it felt heavier than I expected it to, but maybe, I thought, that was because of the included bridge. Upon opening the box I found three bulbs packaged beside each other. I removed the upper cardboard piece and below it was the fourth bulb along with the bridge, power supply, cords, and instructions. This was where I realized that the weight wasn't only the bridge: these bulbs are wonderfully heavy! I have a pack of four Fovaa bulbs and the whole pack doesn't weigh as much as a single Hue bulb. I haven't even put power to a Hue bulb yet and I already feel confident in what I have purchased. Next I opened the instruction booklet; and as professional as everything else in the box feels, I was disappointed with the instructions. They are basically a collection of stick drawings with no textual guidance whatsoever. I was not daunted, though, since there is so much help available online.

The Hue bulbs are more expensive than the bargain brands and I wondered why until I began researching them. Philips uses Zigbee radios in their bulbs and bridges which increases the cost significantly. And after holding one of the bulbs in my hand I could actually feel the difference in quality compared to the other bulbs that I own (Fovaa). Until I actually put these bulbs into service I can't comment on their function, but I expect to be very satisfied with them. My Fovaa bulbs work very well, although when set to blue or green they are not as bright as I think they should be. I am expecting much better brightness with the Hue bulbs. I have read that Wyze makes some really good bulbs in terms of color output that rival the Hue bulbs. Still, the Hue bulbs are constructed differently and are able to do some things that the others evidently cannot do. Once I have these lights going and I have a chance to put them through their paces I will report back with some updates. I'm anxious to try a simulated fireworks display and am hoping that four bulbs are enough to do it. Some of the scenes and animations require more than four bulbs to get the color mixtures right, but I think that a fireworks display could be done using white plus three other colors. At least a small fireworks display. I'll let you know when I have tried it.

Edit 2-12-2024
OK, I have the lights up and running and I can give you a little more insight now. First of all, if you look at the many photos of Hue lights you will know exactly what to expect in terms of color. These bulbs have colors that are full and rich yet are mellowed a bit as they are made to provide ambience to a space instead of producing stark coloring. You can get very deep blues, greens, and reds, and still have good brightness. A word that comes to mind is pastel, and yet the colors can be much deeper than pastel; in fact, the room color can become very red, very blue, very green, and yet still maintain some small bit of pastel quality. Again, I'd say look at a lot of the available pictures and you will know. In contrast to this, my Fovaa bulbs give very dark blues, reds, greens with no mellowing at all. There is no way to brighten the Fovaa bulbs when those colors are cranked to the maximum and maybe that is as it should be. Then again, I have read articles that claim Wyze bulbs have more intense colors than Fovaa bulbs (in fact they are ranked close to the top of all bulbs in that category) and also have more brightness; so it may be more a matter of design. If you want absolute, saturated, bright colors with no compromise you might want to try the Wyze bulbs; however, if you want lights that are tailor made for enhancing the atmosphere of your living spaces I can't imagine a better choice than Hue lights. I want to reiterate here just how good the bulbs feel in the hand, and after screwing them in and setting them up how good they look in action. Something else to touch on is that there are numerous apps available in addition to the official Hue app that can add to the functions your Hue lights can perform. The fireworks display I referred to above is in one of those apps: the app is called "hueDynamic" and the fireworks is under the Experiences heading. The fireworks display cycles your bulb colors mimicking real fireworks. The colors ramp on and off at speeds that seem realistic and your room is bathed in a frenzied display of light. Now that I have tried it I probably won't ever use it again, but hey, these lights can do that! Some other, more restful effects on the menu are flickering candles and a fireplace. If I actually had a fireplace I could see myself using that to enhance the natural flicker of flames. The candles...maybe I will use that one, maybe not. The animations can actually be rather distracting. The ambience settings are probably the most useful, but I should tell you that it is better to have the bulbs located next to walls so that the reflected light can add to the overall effect. I have mine temporarily in a ceiling fan in the middle of the living room and looking up at the light you can see all four bulbs with different colors and it doesn't look so good. Eventually they will be relocated to individual lamps around the room where they should provide a much better experience.

If you buy any bulbs other than Hue bulbs you will be tied to one single app: the official app from the manufacturer of the bulbs. Or you may be limited to tying in to Alexa and the set of skills available because your choice of bulbs doesn't even have an app. With Hue bulbs you have many choices of apps, and you will find that Hue apps, even the third party apps, have a level of professionalism not found in apps for other bulbs. Yes, Hue bulbs cost more...but you will get what you paid for. Top quality, great looking light, an almost endless list of ways to use them; Hue bulbs are probably the very best you can buy.

Data:
I’ve wanted some of the lights for a long time!

This is actually my second shipment of the same product, because the wall plug was bent on the first one. Amazon sent me a new one, and it works like a dream.

Let me start by saying I put these lights in my bedroom and bathroom. My bathroom has a slot for four lights, but I only put two in. I had been using the type of lights that get really hot, which isn’t what you want when you like to take hot showers. Plus, they never got that bright, so really, what’s the point? I figured using two in my bathroom would probably be equivalent to the amount of light I was already getting, so I went for it. You know those really nice, well lit bathrooms in magazines? They must have been using Hue lights, because just two lights on the “energize” setting can illuminate the furthest corner. Man, I need to clean now!

My bedroom lights are the “fun” lights. I’ve been playing with the dimmer and colors for the past day. You can make both bulbs the same color, or you can make each a different color. If you can imagine it, Hue can do it. I’ve only scratched the surface of what they can do.

I don’t integrate my smart devices with Alexa, even though I have two Echos. I do it through the HomeKit app on my iPhone, so I can’t speak for how it works with Alexa, but Siri does a pretty good job. The only thing that’s bothersome is I keep wanting to flip the light switch! I’ll have to get one of the Hue dimmers at some point.

If you’re looking to put a little pizzazz in your home, I’d definitely recommend getting this kit and trying it out. The bulbs are expensive, so it’ll be a gradual integration. Pick a room or two you spend most of your time in, and screw these bad boys in and have some fun!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2024
Data:
I have my house outfitted with Hue lighting and other devices controlled via Google Home. Recently, I purchased a set of four white/color 1100 lumen bulbs, but only one would connect to my bridge. To troubleshoot, I bought a 'starter kit' with four more bulbs, wondering if my bridge was full or outdated. Surprisingly, two bulbs from the new set also wouldn't connect to the new bridge. The bulbs that did connect did so very quickly, while those that didn’t connect required manual entry of their serial numbers for multiple attempts. I received four additional bulbs, and these connected immediately.

After a lot of swapping and rotating near the bridge, using both the automatic find option and the serial number method, I managed to connect eight of the bulbs, but interestingly, not to the new bridge. Before starting, I had updated both bridges to the latest firmware, and they were identical. In the end, while I love the rich color depth and reliability of Hue lights, this experience has made me question the quality of the newer models. Has anyone else experienced similar issues? Additionally, I used the third-party app 'Hue Essentials,' as well as various YouTube tutorials, to connect and reset the bulbs.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2024
Data:
I have my house outfitted with Hue lighting and other devices controlled via Google Home. Recently, I purchased a set of four white/color 1100 lumen bulbs, but only one would connect to my bridge. To troubleshoot, I bought a 'starter kit' with four more bulbs, wondering if my bridge was full or outdated. Surprisingly, two bulbs from the new set also wouldn't connect to the new bridge. The bulbs that did connect did so very quickly, while those that didn’t connect required manual entry of their serial numbers for multiple attempts. I received four additional bulbs, and these connected immediately.

After a lot of swapping and rotating near the bridge, using both the automatic find option and the serial number method, I managed to connect eight of the bulbs, but interestingly, not to the new bridge. Before starting, I had updated both bridges to the latest firmware, and they were identical. In the end, while I love the rich color depth and reliability of Hue lights, this experience has made me question the quality of the newer models. Has anyone else experienced similar issues? Additionally, I used the third-party app 'Hue Essentials,' as well as various YouTube tutorials, to connect and reset the bulbs.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
Data:
Hue first impressions. The box arrived a few minutes ago and it felt heavier than I expected it to, but maybe, I thought, that was because of the included bridge. Upon opening the box I found three bulbs packaged beside each other. I removed the upper cardboard piece and below it was the fourth bulb along with the bridge, power supply, cords, and instructions. This was where I realized that the weight wasn't only the bridge: these bulbs are wonderfully heavy! I have a pack of four Fovaa bulbs and the whole pack doesn't weigh as much as a single Hue bulb. I haven't even put power to a Hue bulb yet and I already feel confident in what I have purchased. Next I opened the instruction booklet; and as professional as everything else in the box feels, I was disappointed with the instructions. They are basically a collection of stick drawings with no textual guidance whatsoever. I was not daunted, though, since there is so much help available online.

The Hue bulbs are more expensive than the bargain brands and I wondered why until I began researching them. Philips uses Zigbee radios in their bulbs and bridges which increases the cost significantly. And after holding one of the bulbs in my hand I could actually feel the difference in quality compared to the other bulbs that I own (Fovaa). Until I actually put these bulbs into service I can't comment on their function, but I expect to be very satisfied with them. My Fovaa bulbs work very well, although when set to blue or green they are not as bright as I think they should be. I am expecting much better brightness with the Hue bulbs. I have read that Wyze makes some really good bulbs in terms of color output that rival the Hue bulbs. Still, the Hue bulbs are constructed differently and are able to do some things that the others evidently cannot do. Once I have these lights going and I have a chance to put them through their paces I will report back with some updates. I'm anxious to try a simulated fireworks display and am hoping that four bulbs are enough to do it. Some of the scenes and animations require more than four bulbs to get the color mixtures right, but I think that a fireworks display could be done using white plus three other colors. At least a small fireworks display. I'll let you know when I have tried it.

Edit 2-12-2024
OK, I have the lights up and running and I can give you a little more insight now. First of all, if you look at the many photos of Hue lights you will know exactly what to expect in terms of color. These bulbs have colors that are full and rich yet are mellowed a bit as they are made to provide ambience to a space instead of producing stark coloring. You can get very deep blues, greens, and reds, and still have good brightness. A word that comes to mind is pastel, and yet the colors can be much deeper than pastel; in fact, the room color can become very red, very blue, very green, and yet still maintain some small bit of pastel quality. Again, I'd say look at a lot of the available pictures and you will know. In contrast to this, my Fovaa bulbs give very dark blues, reds, greens with no mellowing at all. There is no way to brighten the Fovaa bulbs when those colors are cranked to the maximum and maybe that is as it should be. Then again, I have read articles that claim Wyze bulbs have more intense colors than Fovaa bulbs (in fact they are ranked close to the top of all bulbs in that category) and also have more brightness; so it may be more a matter of design. If you want absolute, saturated, bright colors with no compromise you might want to try the Wyze bulbs; however, if you want lights that are tailor made for enhancing the atmosphere of your living spaces I can't imagine a better choice than Hue lights. I want to reiterate here just how good the bulbs feel in the hand, and after screwing them in and setting them up how good they look in action. Something else to touch on is that there are numerous apps available in addition to the official Hue app that can add to the functions your Hue lights can perform. The fireworks display I referred to above is in one of those apps: the app is called "hueDynamic" and the fireworks is under the Experiences heading. The fireworks display cycles your bulb colors mimicking real fireworks. The colors ramp on and off at speeds that seem realistic and your room is bathed in a frenzied display of light. Now that I have tried it I probably won't ever use it again, but hey, these lights can do that! Some other, more restful effects on the menu are flickering candles and a fireplace. If I actually had a fireplace I could see myself using that to enhance the natural flicker of flames. The candles...maybe I will use that one, maybe not. The animations can actually be rather distracting. The ambience settings are probably the most useful, but I should tell you that it is better to have the bulbs located next to walls so that the reflected light can add to the overall effect. I have mine temporarily in a ceiling fan in the middle of the living room and looking up at the light you can see all four bulbs with different colors and it doesn't look so good. Eventually they will be relocated to individual lamps around the room where they should provide a much better experience.

If you buy any bulbs other than Hue bulbs you will be tied to one single app: the official app from the manufacturer of the bulbs. Or you may be limited to tying in to Alexa and the set of skills available because your choice of bulbs doesn't even have an app. With Hue bulbs you have many choices of apps, and you will find that Hue apps, even the third party apps, have a level of professionalism not found in apps for other bulbs. Yes, Hue bulbs cost more...but you will get what you paid for. Top quality, great looking light, an almost endless list of ways to use them; Hue bulbs are probably the very best you can buy.

Data:
I’ve wanted some of the lights for a long time!

This is actually my second shipment of the same product, because the wall plug was bent on the first one. Amazon sent me a new one, and it works like a dream.

Let me start by saying I put these lights in my bedroom and bathroom. My bathroom has a slot for four lights, but I only put two in. I had been using the type of lights that get really hot, which isn’t what you want when you like to take hot showers. Plus, they never got that bright, so really, what’s the point? I figured using two in my bathroom would probably be equivalent to the amount of light I was already getting, so I went for it. You know those really nice, well lit bathrooms in magazines? They must have been using Hue lights, because just two lights on the “energize” setting can illuminate the furthest corner. Man, I need to clean now!

My bedroom lights are the “fun” lights. I’ve been playing with the dimmer and colors for the past day. You can make both bulbs the same color, or you can make each a different color. If you can imagine it, Hue can do it. I’ve only scratched the surface of what they can do.

I don’t integrate my smart devices with Alexa, even though I have two Echos. I do it through the HomeKit app on my iPhone, so I can’t speak for how it works with Alexa, but Siri does a pretty good job. The only thing that’s bothersome is I keep wanting to flip the light switch! I’ll have to get one of the Hue dimmers at some point.

If you’re looking to put a little pizzazz in your home, I’d definitely recommend getting this kit and trying it out. The bulbs are expensive, so it’ll be a gradual integration. Pick a room or two you spend most of your time in, and screw these bad boys in and have some fun!

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2023
Data:
This is a really good starter kit for creating your smart home or smart office. Because of the hub, this has been the most reliable smart light system I’ve ever used. The lights are not the brightest, and their RGB colors are wildly inaccurate, but they always turn on and off when commanded without any lag.

Setting up the hub is not easy - make sure to do it in the Hue app first if planning to add accessories that aren’t just light bulbs. Of the 4 bulbs in the pack, only 2 wanted to automatically connect. I had to manually add the other 2 using their serial numbers. Once all connected to Hue, adding to Apple HomeKit is easy, though I did experience some weird errors where the names and rooms would sometimes not match.

The Hue system is wildly expensive. There are so many other cheaper options. But also, it always works flawlessly once set up, which is better than most other systems can claim.

Date: Reviewed in Mexico on June 26, 2020
Data:
El principal motivo por el que las compre fue por su función de atenuación de Luz (para disfrutar de la TV con menos luz) y el control remoto desde el celular (No más preocupaciones de haber dejado la luz encendida) Sin necesidad de instalaciones adicionales y he quedado satisfecho.

Definitivamente hay muchas tecnologías de smart lights en el Mercado, pero esta fue la que me convenció a mí, como quiera les recomiendo ver reviews a fondo y videos en YouTube.

Mi casa no es muy grande así que la limitante de solo poder conectar 50 dispositivos al Bridge es suficiente para mí. A diferencia de otras tecnologías, a mi no me molesta tener el bridge conectado al módem por cable de red, así me aseguro de poder administrar las luces de manera remota aún cuando no estoy en casa (siempre y cuando tenga luz e internet en la casa).

Puede ser muy confuso al principio y para personas de la tercera edad, ya que el botón de la Luz física del foco debe permanecer encendida todo el tiempo y la luz se controla con la aplicación del celular, Siri, Alexa o Home Kit. Así que si estás muy acostumbrado a usar el botón físico del apagador, puede que te cueste un poco de tiempo acostumbrarte, y la otra es no olvidar el celular ya que solo con el podrás manipular las luces.

La gana de colores también es muy amplia y se ven muy bien, el puente y los focos son la versión 3.

Una duda grande que yo tenía era qué pasa cuando se va la luz? ya que todos los botones físicos estarían encendidos y cuando volviera la luz estarían todos los focos encendidos. La respuesta es que la aplicación te deja configurar manualmente los focos para que conserven el último estado en el que los dejaste antes del apagón (encendidos o apagados). De otra manera, los focos se encienden automáticamente después del apagón.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
Data:
Hue first impressions. The box arrived a few minutes ago and it felt heavier than I expected it to, but maybe, I thought, that was because of the included bridge. Upon opening the box I found three bulbs packaged beside each other. I removed the upper cardboard piece and below it was the fourth bulb along with the bridge, power supply, cords, and instructions. This was where I realized that the weight wasn't only the bridge: these bulbs are wonderfully heavy! I have a pack of four Fovaa bulbs and the whole pack doesn't weigh as much as a single Hue bulb. I haven't even put power to a Hue bulb yet and I already feel confident in what I have purchased. Next I opened the instruction booklet; and as professional as everything else in the box feels, I was disappointed with the instructions. They are basically a collection of stick drawings with no textual guidance whatsoever. I was not daunted, though, since there is so much help available online.

The Hue bulbs are more expensive than the bargain brands and I wondered why until I began researching them. Philips uses Zigbee radios in their bulbs and bridges which increases the cost significantly. And after holding one of the bulbs in my hand I could actually feel the difference in quality compared to the other bulbs that I own (Fovaa). Until I actually put these bulbs into service I can't comment on their function, but I expect to be very satisfied with them. My Fovaa bulbs work very well, although when set to blue or green they are not as bright as I think they should be. I am expecting much better brightness with the Hue bulbs. I have read that Wyze makes some really good bulbs in terms of color output that rival the Hue bulbs. Still, the Hue bulbs are constructed differently and are able to do some things that the others evidently cannot do. Once I have these lights going and I have a chance to put them through their paces I will report back with some updates. I'm anxious to try a simulated fireworks display and am hoping that four bulbs are enough to do it. Some of the scenes and animations require more than four bulbs to get the color mixtures right, but I think that a fireworks display could be done using white plus three other colors. At least a small fireworks display. I'll let you know when I have tried it.

Edit 2-12-2024
OK, I have the lights up and running and I can give you a little more insight now. First of all, if you look at the many photos of Hue lights you will know exactly what to expect in terms of color. These bulbs have colors that are full and rich yet are mellowed a bit as they are made to provide ambience to a space instead of producing stark coloring. You can get very deep blues, greens, and reds, and still have good brightness. A word that comes to mind is pastel, and yet the colors can be much deeper than pastel; in fact, the room color can become very red, very blue, very green, and yet still maintain some small bit of pastel quality. Again, I'd say look at a lot of the available pictures and you will know. In contrast to this, my Fovaa bulbs give very dark blues, reds, greens with no mellowing at all. There is no way to brighten the Fovaa bulbs when those colors are cranked to the maximum and maybe that is as it should be. Then again, I have read articles that claim Wyze bulbs have more intense colors than Fovaa bulbs (in fact they are ranked close to the top of all bulbs in that category) and also have more brightness; so it may be more a matter of design. If you want absolute, saturated, bright colors with no compromise you might want to try the Wyze bulbs; however, if you want lights that are tailor made for enhancing the atmosphere of your living spaces I can't imagine a better choice than Hue lights. I want to reiterate here just how good the bulbs feel in the hand, and after screwing them in and setting them up how good they look in action. Something else to touch on is that there are numerous apps available in addition to the official Hue app that can add to the functions your Hue lights can perform. The fireworks display I referred to above is in one of those apps: the app is called "hueDynamic" and the fireworks is under the Experiences heading. The fireworks display cycles your bulb colors mimicking real fireworks. The colors ramp on and off at speeds that seem realistic and your room is bathed in a frenzied display of light. Now that I have tried it I probably won't ever use it again, but hey, these lights can do that! Some other, more restful effects on the menu are flickering candles and a fireplace. If I actually had a fireplace I could see myself using that to enhance the natural flicker of flames. The candles...maybe I will use that one, maybe not. The animations can actually be rather distracting. The ambience settings are probably the most useful, but I should tell you that it is better to have the bulbs located next to walls so that the reflected light can add to the overall effect. I have mine temporarily in a ceiling fan in the middle of the living room and looking up at the light you can see all four bulbs with different colors and it doesn't look so good. Eventually they will be relocated to individual lamps around the room where they should provide a much better experience.

If you buy any bulbs other than Hue bulbs you will be tied to one single app: the official app from the manufacturer of the bulbs. Or you may be limited to tying in to Alexa and the set of skills available because your choice of bulbs doesn't even have an app. With Hue bulbs you have many choices of apps, and you will find that Hue apps, even the third party apps, have a level of professionalism not found in apps for other bulbs. Yes, Hue bulbs cost more...but you will get what you paid for. Top quality, great looking light, an almost endless list of ways to use them; Hue bulbs are probably the very best you can buy.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
Data:
Hue first impressions. The box arrived a few minutes ago and it felt heavier than I expected it to, but maybe, I thought, that was because of the included bridge. Upon opening the box I found three bulbs packaged beside each other. I removed the upper cardboard piece and below it was the fourth bulb along with the bridge, power supply, cords, and instructions. This was where I realized that the weight wasn't only the bridge: these bulbs are wonderfully heavy! I have a pack of four Fovaa bulbs and the whole pack doesn't weigh as much as a single Hue bulb. I haven't even put power to a Hue bulb yet and I already feel confident in what I have purchased. Next I opened the instruction booklet; and as professional as everything else in the box feels, I was disappointed with the instructions. They are basically a collection of stick drawings with no textual guidance whatsoever. I was not daunted, though, since there is so much help available online.

The Hue bulbs are more expensive than the bargain brands and I wondered why until I began researching them. Philips uses Zigbee radios in their bulbs and bridges which increases the cost significantly. And after holding one of the bulbs in my hand I could actually feel the difference in quality compared to the other bulbs that I own (Fovaa). Until I actually put these bulbs into service I can't comment on their function, but I expect to be very satisfied with them. My Fovaa bulbs work very well, although when set to blue or green they are not as bright as I think they should be. I am expecting much better brightness with the Hue bulbs. I have read that Wyze makes some really good bulbs in terms of color output that rival the Hue bulbs. Still, the Hue bulbs are constructed differently and are able to do some things that the others evidently cannot do. Once I have these lights going and I have a chance to put them through their paces I will report back with some updates. I'm anxious to try a simulated fireworks display and am hoping that four bulbs are enough to do it. Some of the scenes and animations require more than four bulbs to get the color mixtures right, but I think that a fireworks display could be done using white plus three other colors. At least a small fireworks display. I'll let you know when I have tried it.

Edit 2-12-2024
OK, I have the lights up and running and I can give you a little more insight now. First of all, if you look at the many photos of Hue lights you will know exactly what to expect in terms of color. These bulbs have colors that are full and rich yet are mellowed a bit as they are made to provide ambience to a space instead of producing stark coloring. You can get very deep blues, greens, and reds, and still have good brightness. A word that comes to mind is pastel, and yet the colors can be much deeper than pastel; in fact, the room color can become very red, very blue, very green, and yet still maintain some small bit of pastel quality. Again, I'd say look at a lot of the available pictures and you will know. In contrast to this, my Fovaa bulbs give very dark blues, reds, greens with no mellowing at all. There is no way to brighten the Fovaa bulbs when those colors are cranked to the maximum and maybe that is as it should be. Then again, I have read articles that claim Wyze bulbs have more intense colors than Fovaa bulbs (in fact they are ranked close to the top of all bulbs in that category) and also have more brightness; so it may be more a matter of design. If you want absolute, saturated, bright colors with no compromise you might want to try the Wyze bulbs; however, if you want lights that are tailor made for enhancing the atmosphere of your living spaces I can't imagine a better choice than Hue lights. I want to reiterate here just how good the bulbs feel in the hand, and after screwing them in and setting them up how good they look in action. Something else to touch on is that there are numerous apps available in addition to the official Hue app that can add to the functions your Hue lights can perform. The fireworks display I referred to above is in one of those apps: the app is called "hueDynamic" and the fireworks is under the Experiences heading. The fireworks display cycles your bulb colors mimicking real fireworks. The colors ramp on and off at speeds that seem realistic and your room is bathed in a frenzied display of light. Now that I have tried it I probably won't ever use it again, but hey, these lights can do that! Some other, more restful effects on the menu are flickering candles and a fireplace. If I actually had a fireplace I could see myself using that to enhance the natural flicker of flames. The candles...maybe I will use that one, maybe not. The animations can actually be rather distracting. The ambience settings are probably the most useful, but I should tell you that it is better to have the bulbs located next to walls so that the reflected light can add to the overall effect. I have mine temporarily in a ceiling fan in the middle of the living room and looking up at the light you can see all four bulbs with different colors and it doesn't look so good. Eventually they will be relocated to individual lamps around the room where they should provide a much better experience.

If you buy any bulbs other than Hue bulbs you will be tied to one single app: the official app from the manufacturer of the bulbs. Or you may be limited to tying in to Alexa and the set of skills available because your choice of bulbs doesn't even have an app. With Hue bulbs you have many choices of apps, and you will find that Hue apps, even the third party apps, have a level of professionalism not found in apps for other bulbs. Yes, Hue bulbs cost more...but you will get what you paid for. Top quality, great looking light, an almost endless list of ways to use them; Hue bulbs are probably the very best you can buy.

Data:
I’ve wanted some of the lights for a long time!

This is actually my second shipment of the same product, because the wall plug was bent on the first one. Amazon sent me a new one, and it works like a dream.

Let me start by saying I put these lights in my bedroom and bathroom. My bathroom has a slot for four lights, but I only put two in. I had been using the type of lights that get really hot, which isn’t what you want when you like to take hot showers. Plus, they never got that bright, so really, what’s the point? I figured using two in my bathroom would probably be equivalent to the amount of light I was already getting, so I went for it. You know those really nice, well lit bathrooms in magazines? They must have been using Hue lights, because just two lights on the “energize” setting can illuminate the furthest corner. Man, I need to clean now!

My bedroom lights are the “fun” lights. I’ve been playing with the dimmer and colors for the past day. You can make both bulbs the same color, or you can make each a different color. If you can imagine it, Hue can do it. I’ve only scratched the surface of what they can do.

I don’t integrate my smart devices with Alexa, even though I have two Echos. I do it through the HomeKit app on my iPhone, so I can’t speak for how it works with Alexa, but Siri does a pretty good job. The only thing that’s bothersome is I keep wanting to flip the light switch! I’ll have to get one of the Hue dimmers at some point.

If you’re looking to put a little pizzazz in your home, I’d definitely recommend getting this kit and trying it out. The bulbs are expensive, so it’ll be a gradual integration. Pick a room or two you spend most of your time in, and screw these bad boys in and have some fun!

As a starter kit it works! The hub is annoying, as it MUST take up a network slot on your router and just sorta sits there taking up that and an outlet. Furthermore, because these are the starter bulbs, there's not much to really say about them in relation to the app. I often find myself off the network and it's kind of annoying you have to be connected directly to the same wifi and can't just access the bulbs at a whim (think Simplisafe and/or other connectivity apps where you can access even if you aren't at home)

As a wakeup timer, works wonders as the lowest setting still feels blinding at 5am. As far as doing anything particularly expressive, I mean they're just a solid color bulb, so y'know... bright/dim. I will say at the brightest setting, one bulb will illuminate a room and furthermore, the actual smoothness of the dimming really surprised us. The brightness doesn't change in sudden increments which is perfect!

Data:

The smart bulbs supposedly require a Philips Hue bridge and separate Philips app to control the lights and while yes, the brand's own app allows you to have smart functionality, they're advertised as compatible with Alexa but it never works. Also, the bridge and app can't be controlled outside your house. So if you want to turn on the lights before you get home, tough luck.

TL;DR: if you're looking for smart bulbs that are Alexa compatible, stop and look elsewhere. These are a waste of money for that until Philips fixes the Alexa compatibility.
